addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord,
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

6 N
o
1591. M
r
Bodeleie to my L./

page.lettertext:
fol.176r
May it please yo
r
good L. by letters inter-
cepted, by certaine of
e garrison of
Berghen
up Zoome
, written from
Rome
from
e College
of Cardinals, to
e
D. of Parma
,
e
D. de Maine
,
Montemarciano
General of
e
Popes
army,
Lan-
driano
e Popes Nuntio, and to
e citie of
Paris,
it should appeere
at
e College was perplexed
upon
e Popes decease, who died
e 15 of Oc
t
lest some alteration should happen to their
prejudice in France. Wherupon
e next day
after
e death of
e Pope, they dispatched sundrie
letters to
e afore named parties, full of en-
couragement to persist in their courses, and
to tru st upon continuance of relief from Rome.
I have sent yo
r
L.
e Copie of their letters to
Paris, and to Marsilio Landriano. The rest to
e D. of Parma, de Maine &c. because they differ
very litle from those
at I send, I have left
uncopied. Of
e
Empero
rs
peace-
makers,
e last occurrence
at we had, was
of their sending to
e D. of Parma for 3 Cornets
of horse to conduct them to
Brussels.
I have
moved
Count Maurice
, who is greatly opposit
to
at Treaty, to cause some companies of horse
that garrison in Berghen and
Breda,
to lie
in waite for their comming, and under pretext
of seeking
e Enemie, to finde those Ambassado
rs
.
The Count hath not only promised to doe it,
but hath given order already for 700 horse to
be imploied to
at purpose. Howbeit it is
fol.176v
a mater concealed from
e
Councel of state
,
for
at he thinkes among many, it may be ether
discovered, or through doutes and delaies be cleane
broken of.
And thus I take my humble leave.
From
e Hage. N
o
6 1591.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden. Tho. Bodley
